newsitem.title: GERMANY: Telekom sale may not hurt shares - Schaeuble.
newsitem.headline: Telekom sale may not hurt shares - Schaeuble.

text.p: The German government wanted to move ahead with a sale of parts of its stake in Deutsche Telekom AG in a manner that does not upset the market for the shares, a top lieutenant of Chancellor Helmut Kohl said on Tuesday.

It was possible to sell a package of shares to an investor like a bank or to a strategic partner of Telekom, said Wolfgang Schaeuble, parliamentary chief of Kohl's Christian Democrats and sister party Christian Social Union.
Such a sale would not violate the promises made in the prospectus Telekom issued last fall as part of its initial public offering, Schaeuble said.
The prospectus said "the sale by the Federal Republic of shares prior to January 1, 2000 is in principle prohibited."
Selling shares to an investor or partner could prevent them from diluting the value of Telekom shares traded in stock markets.
Bonn owns 74 percent, or 2.03 billion, of Telekom shares, valued at current prices at about 78.4 billion marks.
The government wants to sell some of its shares ahead of schedule to help narrow a gaping budget deficit and to help Germany qualify for European monetary union.
